What was the main purpose of synthesizing the porous coordination polymer with a pyridinium cationic surface?
data.answer: To investigate the methanol absorptive ability of the pyridinium cationic surface.

data.question: How was the isosteric heat of adsorption for methanol calculated?
data.answer: Using a virial-type equation in conjunction with three temperature isotherms.

data.question: What was the result of the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) performed on the synthesized polymer?
data.answer: It showed a weight loss of 18.9% from 298 to 423 K, corresponding to the loss of two DMFs and one H2O per formula unit.

data.question: What structural transformation was observed during the methanol adsorption process?
data.answer: The early two and three methanol inclusions induce the shrinkage and expansion of the 2D porous layers from the framework of the as-synthesized polymer.

data.question: What was the role of the pyridinium cationic surface in the adsorption of methanol?
data.answer: The pyridinium cationic surface participated in the strong adsorption of methanol.

data.question: Why was the contribution of solvent electron density removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON?
data.answer: Because the solvent molecules in the structure were highly disordered at 213 K.

data.question: What indicates the permanent porosity of the synthesized polymer?
data.answer: The nitrogen sorption isotherm at 77 K for the polymer shows permanent porosity.

data.question: How does the synthesis process contribute to the absence of counteranions in the porous coordination polymer?
data.answer: The synthesis process results in a polymer that does not include any counteranion from the starting materials, such as OH-, NO3-, and PF6-.
